summary: duck enteritis virus (DEV), a member of the alphaherpesvirinae subfamily of the order anseriformes, is an acute, contagious virus infection that naturally occurs in ducks, geese and swans. in susceptible flocks, this disease can be transmitted by direct contact or indirectly through environmental contamination. it causes significant economic losses in domestic and wild waterfowl as a result of mortality, and decreased egg production. resveratrol was tested for antiviral activity against DEV. it is also a member of the alphaherpesvirinae subfamily of the herpesviridae. this paper aims to evaluate the antiviral properties of resveratrol. the cytotoxic effect of resveratrol on DEFs monolayers was determined by quantifying the cell viability using an MTT (3-[4.5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl]-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide; Sigma, USA) assay. dilution medium without the sample was used as control. the unabsorbed virus washed with PBS and medium only with dilutions of the test samples were added to the plates respectively. the concentrations of the test samples were equal or less than MNCC. the virus-infected cells without drug treatment and the un-infected cells were used as the controls. the primers and probe were designed using the Primer software. the upstream and downstream primer sequences were 5′-CCCAAACACGAAACATGC-3′ and 5′- TGTCCGGTTACAATATCGTT -3′ respectively. the probe was synthesized by Invitrogen Trading CO., LTD. DNA was extracted from DEV infected DEFs at an MOI of 0.1 for 1 h at 37°C. the cells were then washed with PBS and overlaid with resveratrol solutions. wells overlaid with MEM without test sample were used as the control. ultrathin (100 nm, Leica UC6), longitudinal sections were then cut and stained with uranyl acetate and lead citrate. indirect immunofluorescence assay The cells grown in coverslips infected with DEV (MOI = 0.1) were incubated in the presence or absence of resveratrol. DEFs without any treatment was used as control (B) resveratrol was widely studied for its anti-proliferative mechanisms by inducing reactive oxygen species production and disrupting the release of cytochrome c from the mitochondrial membrane. in traditional antiviral research, the antiviral activities of test samples were confirmed mainly based on their capability to reduce virus titer. resveratrol affected the early stage of the DEV replication cycle. a host nuclear transcription factor activated by HSV infection was suppressed by resveratrol. the synthesis of viral DNA was impaired by resveratrol. resveratrol could inhibit DNA of ASFV replication, late viral protein synthesis and viral factory formation. resveratrol could effectively inhibit DEV in host cells. resveratrol does not inactivate the virus in an extracellular manner.
